Award.AwardTitle: Multiphoton Ionization and Dissociation: The Phase-space View
Award.AbstractNarration:
Laser-driven collisions of electrons and atoms--so-called "recollisions"-- are a key process in ultrastrong lasers. Understanding their role in various laser field configurations is potentially very rewarding for tracking the motion of giant molecules by taking their snapshots in real time. A mechanism which accounts for the rich physics in these strong laser fields is urgently needed. In particular, the impact of recolliding electrons "hitching rides" on special orbits on their way to and from the atom will be researched using mechanical models.

Mechanical treatments of atoms are the perfect physics education and training tool because they allow many atomic properties to be understood pictorially and with comparatively little effort. In addition to graduate student training, undergraduate research projects on classical dynamics will be a component of this research program, as will advising mathematics and science teachers at high schools and technical colleges on pedagogical aspects of atoms. This research is often viewed as a valuable source for applications by mathematicians, and a source of new insights by chemists and therefore serves to strengthen the research infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imagine all the insights into disease prevention and treatment if we could take snapshots of biomolecules moving in real time! Realizing this dream will require unprecedented new light sources, and the laser physics community is hard at work on these sources.  They find that the best way to construct such sources is to first remove electrons from molecules using ultrastrong, ultrashort laser pulses, then energize them using lasers and finally hurl the energetic electrons onto their parent molecules. The hitch is that most of these electrons drift far from their parent molecules in a strong laser field and are therefore lost to us.  However, a few --very few-- find their way back to their parent molecule, and bring with them the energy they absorbed from the laser, and thereby become sources of energy for the light sources physicists are after.

That's why predicting which ionized electrons will return to their parent molecule and which will not matters greatly.  These researchers  are in a position to do just that thanks to their work of the last six years which shows, very surprisingly,  that resonances of the molecule-field system, determine the conditions that will lead to a ``recollision'', which is shorthand for these rare, but significant return processes. Before they entered this field it was generally known that some critical quantum aspects of strong-field physics could be understood by classical mechanics: Indeed, the standard working model of recollision physics, the so-called ``three-step'' scenario consisting of ``ionization/travel in the laser field/return to the core'', views key components of multiple ionization and from a classical plasma perspective. However, they are the first group to exploit this insight using their method of choice, nonlinear dynamics which is ideally suited to uncovering mechanisms. By focusing on the collective behavior of ensembles of trajectories rather than individual trajectories, they have explained quite a few paradoxes in recollision phenomena which had remained unresolved because no feasible computational method was available to investigate them. Their plan for the next few years call for solving realistic versions of the one- and two-dimensional model problems of the past six years. In the process, they will be entering uncharted mathematical territory and have therefore linked up with mathematicians and celestial mechanicians to solve these problems.

The project contributes to the development of human resources through senior people mentoring and training graduate students on a one-on-one basis in rigorous and computational nonlinear dynamics alongside with superintense laser-atom interactions. Nonlinear dynamical methods are applicable in a wide variety of contexts and therefore their new skills will be useful to them in their future careers in science, engineering or technology.
